choices.text: Temperature of growth was set wrong
E. coli produced colicin that inhibited S. epidermidis growth
Gram positives have more generation time

questions.text: In a laboratory experiment, both Staphylococcus epidermidis and Escherichia coli were cultured on the same media. After overnight incubation, it was observed that only E. coli showed significant growth, while S. epidermidis did not grow at all. What could be the most likely reason for this difference in the growth observed in the culture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Culture media was selective. 

 

Option B:

 

The selective growth of only E. coli and not S. epidermidis suggests that the culture media used was selective in nature. Selective media are designed to suppress the growth of some microorganisms while allowing others to grow, which can be achieved through the addition of specific agents that inhibit certain bacteria. In this case, the media might have contained agents that inhibit the growth of Gram-positive bacteria like S. epidermidis, allowing only Gram-negative bacteria like E. coli to flourish.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Temperature of growth was set wrong:  Both S. epidermidis and E. coli can grow at a similar range of temperatures.

 

Option C. E. coli produced colicin that inhibited S. epidermidis growth:  is a possibility, as colicins are bacteriocins produced by some E. coli strains. However, their presence and effect would be more specific and not as commonly encountered in a routine lab setting.

 

Option D. Gram positives have more generation time is not a relevant factor in this context; both bacteria can grow well under standard lab conditions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The role of selective media is demonstrated by the selective growth of Escherichia coli over Staphylococcus epidermidis in a laboratory setting. The media's selective nature, possibly containing agents that inhibit the growth of Gram-positive bacteria like S. epidermidis, allowing the growth of Gram-negative bacteria like E. coli, highlights the importance of choosing appropriate media for culturing different bacterial types. 

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 31/4e

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with a severe bacterial infection. During diagnostic testing, a Gram stain of the causative organism reveals a pink/red coloration. Based on this Gram staining result, which component(s) are characteristic of the cell wall of this organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lipopolysaccharides.

 

Option B:

 

The pink/red coloration on Gram staining indicates that the causative agent is a Gram-negative bacterium. A characteristic feature of the cell wall of Gram-negative bacteria is the presence of an outer membrane that contains lipopolysaccharides (LPS). LPS is significant in contributing to the structural integrity of the cell wall and in triggering an immune response in the host.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Peptidoglycan:  Present in both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, but it is not the distinguishing or characteristic feature for a Gram-negative bacterium as its layer is much thinner in these organisms compared to Gram-positive bacteria.

 

Option C. Lipids: General component of cell membranes but are not specific enough to be the defining feature of a Gram-negative bacterium's cell wall.

 

Option D. Teichoic acid: Component found in the cell walls of Gram-positive bacteria, not Gram-negative.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 16/4e

choices.text: Toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic
Carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, and methylene blue

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a thick, gray coating on the throat and tonsils, accompanied by symptoms including fever, chills, and swollen glands, persisting for a week. A nasopharyngeal or pharyngeal swab is taken for microscopic examination, revealing a Gram-positive organism having the angulated appearance that requires a special stain for identification. Which combination of constituents is most likely used in the stain for this particular examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic

 

Option B:

 

The patient's symptoms and the description of the organism suggest a diagnosis of diphtheria, caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The Gram stain, which is a common method used to classify bacteria and guide treatment, is typically used in this scenario showing gram positive organism.


A special stain used for Corynebacterium diphtheriae is Albert staining which contains Toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic. The organism is visible as green bacilli with bluish-black metachromatic granules at the poles. 
 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Crystal violet, Gram’s iodine: Gram staining can be used for detecting Corynebacterium diphtheriae but it is not specific staining technique for it.

 

Option C. Carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, and methylene blue- used in the Ziehl-Neelsen staining method, primarily for identifying acid-fast bacilli such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, not Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Option D. Methylene Blue: is used as a simple stain but not typically for identifying Gram-positive organisms in the context described.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

 A special stain used for Corynebacterium diphtheriae is Albert staining which contains Toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic. The organism is visible as green bacilli with bluish-black metachromatic granules at the poles. 

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 27/4e

choices.text: Faster lag phase in enrichment medium
Slower log phase in enrichment medium
Higher bacterial count at stationary phase in enrichment medium
Earlier death phase in enrichment medium

questions.text: A microbiology resident is comparing the growth patterns of a bacterial culture under two different conditions: on a standard growth medium and in an enrichment medium. She notices distinct differences in the bacterial growth curves under these two conditions. Which of the following best describes the difference in bacterial growth in an enrichment medium compared to a standard growth medium?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Higher bacterial count at stationary phase in enrichment medium. 

 

Option C:
 

Enrichment media are designed to promote the growth of a particular group of microorganisms by providing essential nutrients and environmental conditions favorable for their growth. As a result, bacteria grown in an enrichment medium typically reach a higher bacterial count at the stationary phase compared to those grown in a standard medium. This is because the enriched environment supports a more extensive proliferation of bacteria before they exhaust the available nutrients and reach the stationary phase.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Faster lag phase in enrichment medium is not necessarily true, as the lag phase is a period of adaptation and does not always correlate with the richness of the medium.

 

Option B. Slower log phase in the enrichment medium is incorrect, as enrichment media are designed to facilitate, not hinder, bacterial growth.

 

Option D. Earlier death phase in the enrichment medium is also incorrect. The death phase is determined by factors like nutrient depletion and waste accumulation, which are not directly influenced by the enrichment of the medium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enhanced bacterial growth in enrichment media compared to standard media is vital in microbiological studies. Bacteria like E. coli, when grown in enrichment media, demonstrate a higher bacterial count at the stationary phase due to the provision of essential nutrients and favorable growth conditions.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 23/4e

questions.text: A research fellow is utilizing PCR techniques for the detection of a specific gene mutation in a sample. She wants to amplify a small amount of DNA to a quantity sufficient for analysis. Which of the following best describes the key component necessary for the PCR process to successfully amplify the DNA?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Taq polymerase enzyme.

 

Option C:

 

PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is a technique used to amplify small segments of DNA. The key component for this process is the Taq polymerase enzyme. This enzyme is thermostable, meaning it can withstand the high temperatures used in PCR to denature the DNA strands. Taq polymerase is responsible for synthesizing new strands of DNA by adding nucleotides to a primer annealed to the template DNA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Reverse transcriptase enzyme is used in reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) for converting RNA into DNA, not in standard PCR.

 

Option B. DNA ligase enzyme is used for joining DNA fragments together, which is not the primary function in the PCR process.

 

Option D. Restriction endonuclease enzyme cuts DNA at specific sequences and is not involved in the amplification process of PCR.

 

Educational Objective:


Taq polymerase enzyme as the key component in the Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) process is crucial for amplifying specific DNA segments. This enzyme's thermostable nature, which allows it to withstand high temperatures used in PCR for denaturing DNA strands, is essential for the synthesis of new DNA strands. 

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 46 /4e

choices.text: Increased specificity due to two rounds of amplification with different primer sets
Elimination of the need for thermal cycling

questions.text: A molecular biologist is employing Nested PCR for the detection of a low-abundance pathogen in a clinical sample. This technique involves two sets of primers and two successive PCR reactions. What is the primary advantage of using Nested PCR compared to traditional PCR methods?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased specificity due to two rounds of amplification with different primer sets. 

 

Option A:

 

Nested PCR is a modification of the standard PCR technique that increases the specificity of DNA amplification. By using two sets of primers in two successive PCR reactions, Nested PCR allows for the amplification of a specific target sequence with greater precision. The first set of primers amplifies a broad region of DNA, and the second set, which is internal to the first amplified sequence, further refines the specificity, reducing the likelihood of non-specific amplification.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Decreased time for amplification is incorrect, as Nested PCR typically takes longer due to the two rounds of PCR.

 

Option C. Reduced need for template DNA is not a primary advantage of Nested PCR. While it can amplify small amounts of DNA, the technique's focus is on specificity, not reducing the amount of template DNA required.

 

Option D. Elimination of the need for thermal cycling is incorrect. Nested PCR, like traditional PCR, still requires thermal cycling for DNA denaturation, primer annealing, and extension.

 

Educational Objective:


Nested PCR enhances the specificity of DNA amplification by using two sets of primers in two successive PCR reactions, thereby reducing the likelihood of non-specific amplification.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 46 /4e

choices.text: Resistance to most beta-lactam antibiotics, including penicillins and third-generation cephalosporins
Dependency on anaerobic conditions for growth

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient is admitted to the hospital with a severe urinary tract infection. Laboratory tests indicate the presence of a bacterial strain producing Extended-Spectrum Beta-Lactamases (ESBLs). Which characteristic is most commonly associated with bacteria that produce ESBLs?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Resistance to most beta-lactam antibiotics, including penicillins and third generation cephalosporins.

 

Option A:


Bacteria that produce Extended-Spectrum Beta-Lactamases (ESBLs) are characterized by their resistance to a wide range of beta-lactam antibiotics. This includes penicillins and third-generation cephalosporins. ESBL enzymes break down these antibiotics, rendering them ineffective. This resistance presents significant challenges in treating infections caused by ESBL-producing organisms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Increased susceptibility to aminoglycosides is incorrect. While ESBL-producing bacteria are often resistant to beta-lactams, this does not inherently make them more susceptible to aminoglycosides.

 

Option C. Dependency on anaerobic conditions for growth is not a characteristic of ESBL-producing bacteria. These bacteria do not specifically require anaerobic conditions.

 

Option D. Natural resistance to carbapenems is incorrect. While some ESBL-producing bacteria may acquire resistance to carbapenems, it is not a natural characteristic of ESBLs. In fact, carbapenems are often used to treat infections caused by ESBL-producing organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key characteristic of bacteria that produce Extended-Spectrum Beta-Lactamases (ESBLs) (Ex: Escherichia coli and Klebsiella pneumoniae) is their resistance to a wide range of beta-lactam antibiotics, including penicillins and third-generation cephalosporins. However, they are not inherently resistant to carbapenems, which are often effective against these infections.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 62 /4e

choices.text: Frictional trauma to the urethra caused by the catheter
Formation of biofilms on the catheter surface
Altered urine pH due to prolonged catheterization
Direct introduction of skin flora into the bladder during catheterization

questions.text: A healthcare team is managing a patient with a long-term indwelling Foley catheter. They are discussing the risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs) associated with the catheter. Which factor contributes most significantly to the increased risk of UTI in patients with an indwelling Foley catheter?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formation of biofilms on the catheter surface

 

Option B:
 

The use of indwelling Foley catheters is a well-known risk factor for urinary tract infections, primarily due to the formation of biofilms on the catheter surface. Biofilms are complex communities of bacteria adhering to surfaces in an extracellular matrix. These biofilms are difficult to eradicate and serve as a reservoir for pathogens, leading to recurrent or persistent infections. The presence of a foreign body, such as a Foley catheter, provides an ideal surface for biofilm formation, thereby significantly increasing the risk of UTIs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Frictional trauma to the urethra caused by the catheter can contribute to discomfort and potential injury but is not the primary factor in UTI risk.

 

Option C. Altered urine pH due to prolonged catheterization may contribute to an environment that favors bacterial growth but is less significant compared to biofilm formation.

 

Option D. Direct introduction of skin flora into the bladder during catheterization is a risk during the initial placement of the catheter, but the ongoing risk of UTI is more associated with biofilm formation.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Formation of biofilms on the surface of indwelling Foley catheters as a significant contributor to the increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs) is vital in healthcare. Biofilms, comprising complex communities of bacteria, are difficult to eradicate and act as a reservoir for pathogens, leading to recurrent or persistent infections.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 69/4e

questions.text: Match the scientist with their identity.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A1, B3, C4, D2

 

Option A:

 

Robert Koch (1843–1910)- Known as ‘father of Bacteriology His major contributions are – 

 

  • Introduced solid media for the culture of bacteria.

  • Methods for isolation of bacteria in pure culture

  • Described hanging drop method for testing motility

  • Discovered bacteria such as the anthrax bacilli, tubercle bacilli and cholera bacilli

  • Introduced staining techniques by using aniline dye

  • Koch’s phenomenon

  • Koch’s postulates: 


Note - Bacteria that do not satisfy one or more of the four criteria of Koch’s Postulates: Mycobacterium leprae; Treponema pallidum and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Louis Pasteur (1822–1895) - Known as ‘father of Modern microbiology’. His contributions are as follows:

 

  • Proposed the principles of fermentation for the preservation of food

  • Introduced the sterilization techniques and developed steam sterilizer, hot air oven and autoclave

  • Described the method of pasteurization of milk

  • Vaccine development against several diseases, such as anthrax, fowl cholera and rabies

  • Disproved the theory of spontaneous generation of disease and postulated the ‘germ theory of disease’. 

  • Liquid media concept: He used the nutrient broth to grow microorganisms

 

Option C. Antonie Philips van Leeuwenhoek (1676) - Known as ‘father of microbiology’.He was the first scientist who observed bacteria and other microorganisms, using a single-lens microscope constructed by him and he named those small organisms as ‘Little animalcules’

 

Option D. PAUL Ehrlich (1867) - Father of  chemotherapy. He formed the Paul Ehrlich institute in Germany, gave the acid fast nature of Tubercule bacilli, discovered the Ehrlichia bacteria, gave the Ehrlich ohenomenon and gave the concept of chain termination theory of antibody production

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Father of Bacteriology - Robert Koch

  • Father of Modern Microbiology - Louis Pasteur

  • Father of Microbiology - Antonie Philips van Leeuwenhoek

  • Father of chemotherapy - Paul Ehrlich

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 4/4e

choices.text: Use of electrons instead of light for imaging

questions.text: In a recent publication in a leading scientific journal, a research team detailed their groundbreaking study on the ultrastructural analysis of a novel viral pathogen. The team employed advanced imaging techniques to visualize the virus at a molecular level, providing insights into its mode of entry into host cells. A significant aspect of their methodology was the choice of electron microscopy over traditional light microscopy, which enabled them to achieve unprecedented resolution and detail in their images. This choice was pivotal for the study's success, as it allowed the researchers to observe structures that were previously too small to be resolved with light microscopy. What feature distinguishes electron microscopy, which was used in this study, from light microscopy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Use of electrons instead of light for imaging

 

Option A:

 

Electron microscopy utilizes a beam of electrons instead of light to image the specimen. The shorter wavelength of electrons allows for much higher resolution and magnification compared to light microscopy.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option B. Use of glass lenses: Electron microscopes use electromagnetic lenses to focus the electron beam, not glass lenses which are used in light microscopy.

 

Option C. Lower resolution than light microscopy: Electron microscopy offers a significantly higher resolution than light microscopy due to the use of electrons (with shorter wavelengths) for imaging.

 

Option D. Limited to living specimens: In fact, electron microscopy is generally not used for living specimens as the process requires a high vacuum and often heavy metal staining, which are not compatible with living tissues.

 

Educational Objective:


The primary distinction of electron microscopy from light microscopy lies in its use of electrons instead of light for imaging. This fundamental difference allows electron microscopy to achieve much higher resolution and magnification, thanks to the shorter wavelength of electrons. 

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg10 /4e

questions.text:
A researcher is using an electron microscope to examine viral particles in a tissue sample from a patient with a suspected novel viral infection. The researcher needs to observe the ultrastructural details of the virus to determine its classification and potential pathogenicity.

 

Question: Which component is critical for producing the high-resolution images required to study the viral particles in the electron microscope?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Electromagnetic lens

 

Option B:

 

The electromagnetic lens is the correct answer. In electron microscopy, electromagnetic lenses are used to focus the electron beam, which is essential for producing high-resolution images. Unlike light microscopes that use glass lenses to focus light, electron microscopes use electromagnetic fields to control the path of electrons, allowing for much higher resolution and the ability to visualize structures at the molecular level.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glass lens: Used in light microscopes, not electron microscopes.

 

Option C. Incandescent light bulb: Provides light in light microscopes, irrelevant in electron microscopy which uses electron beams.

 

Option D. Photographic film: While used to capture images in some types of microscopes, it is not the critical component for high-resolution image production in electron microscopes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The critical role of electromagnetic lenses in electron microscopy is essential for producing high-resolution images. Unlike light microscopes that utilize glass lenses to focus light, electron microscopes employ electromagnetic lenses to focus the electron beam. This distinction is crucial in achieving the significantly higher resolution characteristic of electron microscopy, enabling the visualization of structures at the molecular level. 

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg10/4e

choices.text: Use of electron beams instead of light
Ability to view live specimens

questions.text: What feature of electron microscopes allows them to achieve greater resolution than light microscopes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Use of electron beams instead of light

 

Option B:

 

Electron beams have shorter wavelengths than visible light, leading to higher resolution.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Larger size of the microscope: Size does not directly relate to resolution.

 

Option C. Use of glass slides: Glass slides are common to many microscopy techniques and do not impact resolution.

 

Option D. Ability to view live specimens: Electron microscopes cannot view live specimens, and this does not relate to resolution.

 

Educational Objective:


The key to the enhanced resolution in electron microscopy lies in its use of electron beams instead of light. This fundamental difference, attributed to the shorter wavelength of electron beams compared to visible light, is what enables electron microscopes to achieve much higher resolution. Understanding this concept is crucial in the field of microscopy, particularly for applications requiring detailed observation at the molecular or atomic level. 

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg10/4e

choices.text: To maintain the integrity and quality of the images produced
To avoid damaging the vacuum system

questions.text: A laboratory technician is preparing biological samples for observation under an electron microscope. Before placing the samples in the microscope, they must undergo a critical preparatory step that involves dehydration. A medical student observing the process inquiries about the purpose of this step. In electron microscopy, why must samples be dehydrated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. To maintain the integrity and quality of the images produced.

 

Option B:

 

Electron microscopy requires that samples be placed in a vacuum because air molecules would scatter the electrons and degrade the quality of the image. If biological samples contain water, the water can vaporize in the vacuum, introducing vapor molecules that would interfere with the electron beam. Therefore, samples are dehydrated to prevent these issues and to preserve the structure of the samples, allowing for high-resolution imaging.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. To increase their size: Dehydration does not purposefully increase sample size.

 

Option C. To avoid damaging the vacuum system While causing damage to the vacuum system is a concern, it's not the primary reason for dehydration.

 

Option D. To enhance color contrast: Incorrect. Electron microscopy images are not in color, and dehydration does not affect contrast in this way.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Dehydration of samples in electron microscopy is crucial to preserve the structure of the samples, allowing for high-resolution imaging.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg10/4e

questions.text: Which type of electron microscopy is best suited for examining internal structures of a cell?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM). 

 

Option B:

 

TEM is used to view thin sections of samples, allowing examination of internal cellular structures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM): Incorrect. SEM is used for surface imaging.

 

Option C. Light Microscopy: Incorrect. While useful, it doesn't provide the same resolution for internal structures as TEM.

 

Option D. X-ray Crystallography: Incorrect. This is used for determining molecular structures, not cellular imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • TEM is for viewing thin sections of samples, providing detailed insight into the internal cellular architecture. 
  • Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), is primarily used for surface imaging, 
  • X-ray Crystallography is used for molecular structure determination rather than cellular imaging.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg10/4e

choices.text: The numerical aperture of the objective lens
The colour of the light used for illumination.
The thickness of the specimen cover glass
The distance between the objective lens and the specimen

questions.text: The resolving power of a light microscope is NOT influenced by which of the following factors?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The colour of the light used for illumination.

 

Option B:

 

While the wavelength of the light (which is related to colour) does affect specimen, the specific color itself does not directly influence resolving power unless it is considered in terms of wavelength.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The numerical aperture of the objective lens: Incorrect. The numerical aperture is directly related to the resolving power; higher numerical apertures allow for greater resolution.

 

Option C. The thickness of the specimen cover glass: Incorrect. The thickness of the cover glass can affect the path of light and thereby influence the resolution to some extent.

 

Option D. The distance between the objective lens and the specimen: Incorrect. The working distance can affect resolution, especially if it deviates significantly from the optimal focal length for which the objective lens is designed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The resolving power of a light microscope is influenced by numerical aperture of the objective lens, thickness of the specimen and distance between the objective lens and the specimen, But not the color of light.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 08/4e

choices.text: Light source with a specific wavelength

questions.text: During a laboratory class, medical students are shown an image of bacteria exhibiting green fluorescence. The instructor explains that a specific component of the microscope is critical for visualizing this type of image. Which component is essential in a microscope to observe fluorescently labeled specimens?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dichroic mirror

 

Option D:

 

The dichroic mirror is crucial in fluorescence microscopy as it reflects the specific wavelength of light used to excite the fluorescent dye and transmits the emitted fluorescence from the sample, enabling the capture of such images.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fluorescence filter set: Incorrect. While essential for selecting the specific wavelengths of light, the filter set alone is not responsible for the generation of the fluorescent signal.

 

Option B. Light source with a specific wavelength: Incorrect. A specific wavelength light source excites the fluorophores, but it's the dichroic mirror that differentiates the emission from excitation light.

 

Option C. Fluorescence objective lens: Incorrect. The objective lens focuses the light on the sample and collects the emitted light, but it does not distinguish between the excitation and emission wavelengths.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dichroic mirror as an essential component of fluorescence microscopy that separates the excitation light from the emitted fluorescence, allowing for the visualization of fluorescently labeled specimens.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 09/4e

choices.text: Add on metronidazole to the current regimen

questions.text: A patient with a history of ESBL-producing Klebsiella pneumoniae bacteremia is currently on ceftriaxone and amikacin. Following treatment, the patient's clinical condition has not improved. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Switch to a carbapenem antibiotic 

 

Option C:

 

Carbapenems are the treatment of choice for serious infections caused by ESBL-producing organisms due to their resistance to hydrolysis by ESBL enzymes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Escalate ceftriaxone dosage: Increasing the dose of ceftriaxone is unlikely to be effective against an ESBL-producing organism.

 

Option B. Add on metronidazole to the current regimen: Metronidazole is primarily used for anaerobic coverage and would not be appropriate for ESBL-producing Klebsiella.

 

Option D. Discontinue amikacin and start vancomycin: Vancomycin is not effective against Gram-negative bacteria like Klebsiella pneumoniae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carbapenems are preferred due to their resistance to hydrolysis by ESBL enzymes, making them effective against ESBL-producing organisms. 

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 65/4e

questions.text: For standardizing an antibiotic sensitivity test, the turbidity of the bacterial suspension should be adjusted to which McFarland standard?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) McFarland 0.5 standard

 

Option A:

 

The McFarland 0.5 standard is commonly used as a reference for adjusting the turbidity of bacterial suspensions to approximate a standard number of bacteria for antibiotic susceptibility testing.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option B. McFarland 1.5 standard: This standard would indicate a denser suspension than typically used for antibiotic sensitivity tests.

 

Option C. McFarland 2.0 standard: A McFarland 2.0 standard is too turbid and would lead to inaccuracies in interpreting antibiotic sensitivity.

 

Option D. McFarland 0.75 standard: While closer to the correct answer, this is not a standard commonly used for this purpose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McFarland standards are used as a reference to adjust the turbidity of bacterial suspensions so that the number of bacteria will be within a given range.

 

  • A 0.5 McFarland standard is prepared by mixing 0.05 mL of barium chloride dihydrate with 9.95 mL of 1% sulfuric acid and its equivalent to 150 million no. of bacteria/mL in a broth.
  • For antibiotic sensitivity test, the organism broth prepared should match with- 0.5 McFarland standard.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 41/4e

questions.text: Which method is not typically used to determine the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of an antibiotic?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Disk diffusion method

 

Option C: 

 

The disk diffusion method, also known as the Kirby-Bauer test, is used for antibiotic susceptibility testing but does not provide an MIC value.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gradient Diffusion Method: Also known as the E-test, can be used to determine MIC.

 

Option B. Broth Microdilution Method: Standard method for determining MIC. 

 

Option D. Agar Dilution Method: Quantitative method that can be used to determine MIC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MIC can be determined by Gradient diffusion method, Broth microdilution method and Agar dilution method.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 41/4e

choices.text: Horizontal gene transfer via  Lysogenic conversion
Horizontal gene transfer via transformation
Vertical gene transfer via binary fission
Gene splicing via recombinant DNA technology

questions.text: A microbiology study is examining the transformation of non-toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae into a toxigenic form through bacteriophage interaction. What genetic transfer method is involved in this conversion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Horizontal gene transfer via  Lysogenic conversion

 

Option A:

 

Lysogenic conversion is a process in which a virus (bacteriophage ) gives its own genetic material to bacteria  .

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Horizontal gene transfer via transformation: Transformation involves the uptake of free DNA from the environment by a bacterial cell, not through a bacteriophage.

 

Option C. Vertical gene transfer via binary fission: Binary fission is a method of asexual reproduction that does not involve genetic transfer through bacteriophages.

 

Option D. Gene splicing via recombinant DNA technology: Recombinant DNA technology is a laboratory method, not a natural process of gene transfer by bacteriophages.

 

Educational Objective:


 

  • Lysogenic conversion is a process in which a virus (bacteriophage) gives its own genetic material to bacteria  
  • Transformation involves the uptake of free DNA from the environment by a bacterial cell, not through a bacteriophage.
  • Binary fission is a method of asexual reproduction.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 52/4e

questions.text: In bacterial genetics, which mechanism allows for the transfer of genetic material via bacteriophages?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transduction

 

Option C:

 

Transduction is the transfer of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Transposition: Involves the movement of transposons within the genome and does not require bacteriophages.

 

Option B. Conjugative Transfer: The direct transfer of DNA from one bacterium to another through direct contact, not via bacteriophages.

 

Option D. Natural Genetic Transformation: Uptake of DNA from the environment, Independent of Bacteriophages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transduction as the mechanism of horizontal gene transfer in bacteria mediated by bacteriophages.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 52/4e

questions.text: What is the typical resolving power of a standard light microscope, which limits its ability to distinguish two closely spaced objects as separate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.2 micrometres

 

Option A:

 

The resolving power of a light microscope, which is the ability to distinguish two points as separate, is generally limited to about 0.2 micrometers (200 nanometers). This limitation is primarily due to the wavelength of visible light used in light microscopy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Exceeds the typical resolving power of a standard light microscope.  

 

Option C. and Option D. Are much larger than the resolving power of a light microscope and would pertain to resolutions achievable by the naked eye or a magnifying glass, not a microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The resolving power of a standard light microscope is typically around 0.2 micrometers, which limits its ability to distinguish closely spaced objects as separate entities.

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 9-10/4e

choices.text: Inhibits the growth of certain microbes
Differentiates between types of bacteria based on their metabolic properties
Enhances the growth of specific bacteria
Contains blood components for fastidious organisms

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of enrichment media in microbiological studies?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enhances the growth of specific bacteria.

 

Option C:

 

Enrichment media are a form of extremely selective medium that only permits a specific species of a microbe to grow in it. These mediums prevent undesirable, commensal, or contaminating microbes from growing. As a result, enrichment media can be used to concentrate on a certain type of microorganism while recovering it from the rest of the medium’s microorganisms.

 

This is typically liquid in their consistency. Selective media is a term used to describe agar-based media that fulfil the same function. Furthermore, antibiotics, dyes, chemicals, pH changes, or a combo of these can be used to increase the selectivity of these media.

 

Examples of enrichment media that are the most prominent are:

 

  • Selenite F broth 
  • Tetrathionate broth
  • Alkaline peptone water (APW)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Inhibits the growth of certain microbes: This describes selective media.

 

Option B. Differentiates between types of bacteria: This is characteristic of differential or indicator media.

 

Option D. Contains blood components: This describes chocolate agar, a type of enriched media, but it is not a defining feature of all enrichment media.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enrichment media are designed to enhance the growth of particular microorganisms, often by providing essential nutrients or conditions that favor the growth of those organisms.
 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 31/4e

choices.text: Enhances the growth of a broad spectrum of organisms.
Suppresses the growth of unwanted bacteria and supports the growth of the organism of interest.
Differentiates organisms based on their biochemical characteristics.

questions.text: What is the primary function of selective media in microbiology?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Suppresses the growth of unwanted bacteria and supports the growth of the organism of interest.

 

Option B:

 

Selective media contain agents that inhibit the growth of some microorganisms while allowing others to grow, making it easier to isolate a specific type of bacteria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Enhances the growth of a broad spectrum of organisms: This is more characteristic of non-selective or general-purpose media.

 

Option C. Differentiates organisms: Pertains to differential or indicator media.

 

Option D. Indicates fermentation of specific sugars: Associated with specific differential media like TSI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selective media as those designed to suppress the growth of certain microorganisms while promoting the growth of others.

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 32/4e

choices.text: For the selective cultivation of gram-positive bacteria.
To differentiate bacteria based on their hemolytic properties.
For the growth of fastidious respiratory bacteria, such as Haemophilus influenzae and Neisseria species.
To enhance the visualization of fungal spores and hyphae.

questions.text: What is the primary use of Chocolate Agar in microbiological cultures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) For the growth of fastidious respiratory bacteria, such as Haemophilus influenzae and Neisseria species.

 

Option C:

 

Chocolate Agar is primarily used for the growth of fastidious respiratory bacteria, such as Haemophilus influenzae and Neisseria species. This medium is enriched and non-selective, containing lysed red blood cells that provide the X and V factors required by some fastidious bacteria, particularly those from respiratory tract specimens.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chocolate Agar is not selective for gram-positive bacteria but is used for the cultivation of fastidious organisms.

 

Option B. Differential media based on hemolytic properties, like Blood Agar, are used to differentiate bacteria, not Chocolate Agar.

 

Option D. Chocolate Agar is not designed for fungal cultivation but for fastidious bacterial species.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chocolate Agar is primarily used in microbiology for the cultivation of fastidious respiratory bacteria, such as Haemophilus influenzae and Neisseria species, due to its enrichment with lysed red blood cells.

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 31/4e

choices.text: To selectively enhance the growth of gram-positive bacteria.
To differentiate enteric bacteria based on their ability to ferment lactose, sucrose, and/or glucose, and to produce hydrogen sulfide.
To identify fungi based on their morphological characteristics.
To distinguish between aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of using Triple Sugar Iron (TSI) agar in microbiological cultures?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To differentiate enteric bacteria based on their ability to ferment lactose, sucrose, and/or glucose, and to produce hydrogen sulfide.

 

Option B:

 

The medium contains three carbohydrates (lactose, sucrose, and glucose) and a sulfur source, which allows for the detection of hydrogen sulfide production.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. TSI agar is not used for the selective growth of gram-positive bacteria but for differentiation of enteric gram-negative bacteria.

 

Option C. TSI agar is not used for identifying fungi.

 

Option D. TSI agar does not distinguish between aerobic and anaerobic bacteria but is used for differentiating bacteria based on carbohydrate fermentation and hydrogen sulfide production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triple Sugar Iron (TSI) agar is used in microbiology to differentiate enteric bacteria based on their carbohydrate fermentation (lactose, sucrose, and glucose) and hydrogen sulfide production abilities.

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 39/4e

questions.text: A microbiology lab receives a sputum sample from a patient with a suspected hospital-acquired pneumonia. The organism isolated grows on Simmons' citrate agar with a blue color change. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Klebsiella pneumoniae

 

Option C:

 

K. pneumoniae can utilize citrate as a sole carbon source, which would lead to a blue color change on Simmons' citrate agar, indicating an alkaline pH due to citrate utilization.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Incorrect. Pseudomonas aeruginosa can use citrate, but it is not typically tested with citrate agar in a clinical setting.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli: Incorrect. E. coli cannot utilize citrate as its sole carbon source under aerobic conditions and would not cause a color change on citrate agar.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Incorrect. Staphylococcus aureus does not utilize citrate in this manner and would not cause a color change on citrate agar.

 

Educational Objective:


Klebsiella pneumoniae as an organism that can utilize citrate as its sole carbon source, leading to a blue color change on Simmons' citrate agar.

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 39/4e

questions.text: During a routine health check-up, a 60-year-old female with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections provides a urine sample that is found to have a high pH. The culture grows pink colonies on urea agar. Which organism is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Proteus mirabilis

 

Option B:

 

P. mirabilis is known for its potent urease activity, which can hydrolyze urea to ammonia, raising the pH of urine and leading to the formation of struvite stones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Escherichia coli: Is not a strong urease producer and does not typically raise the pH of urine significantly.

 

Option C. Enterococcus faecalis: While Enterococcus can cause urinary tract infections, it is not known for urease production or significantly raising urine pH.

 

Option D. Klebsiella pneumoniae: Klebsiella can be a urease producer but is not as strongly associated with alkaline urine as Proteus species.

 

Educational Objective:


Proteus mirabilis as a urease-producing organism that can raise the pH of urine and grow pink colonies on urea agar.

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 39/4e

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with fever and right upper quadrant abdominal pain. Blood cultures grow a Gram-negative rod. The organism is inoculated on TSI agar, showing acid slant/acid butt with gas production. This biochemical reaction pattern is most consistent with which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Escherichia coli

 

Option B:

 

E. coli is a lactose-fermenting, gas-producing organism, which would produce an acid slant and acid butt with gas on TSI agar.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Shigella dysenteriae: Shigella species typically produce an alkaline slant and acid butt without gas on TSI agar, reflecting their non-lactose fermenting, non-gas producing characteristics.

 

Option C. Salmonella typhi:  Salmonella species usually produce an alkaline slant and acid butt with gas on TSI agar because they do not ferment lactose but do ferment glucose and other sugars.

 

Option D. Vibrio cholerae: Vibrio species do not typically produce an acid slant on TSI agar as they are not lactose fermenters.

 

Educational Objective:


Escherichia coli as a lactose-fermenting, gas-producing organism that would show an acid slant/acid butt with gas production on TSI agar.

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 39/4e

questions.text: In the clinical laboratory, which method is considered the gold standard for antimicrobial susceptibility testing of bacteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Broth microdilution

 

Option C:

 

Broth microdilution is considered the gold standard for determining MIC values for antimicrobial susceptibility testing.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. E-test: Incorrect. The E-test is used for susceptibility testing, but it is not the gold standard.

 

Option B. Disk diffusion: Incorrect. The disk diffusion (Kirby-Bauer) test is commonly used, but it does not provide MIC values.

 

Option D. Automated systems: Incorrect. While useful, automated systems are not the definitive gold standard; they often rely on broth microdilution principles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Broth microdilution as the gold standard method for antimicrobial susceptibility testing to determine minimum inhibitory concentrations (MICs) of antibiotics against bacteria.

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 41/4e

choices.text: Modification of the target peptidoglycan precursor
Enzymatic degradation of the drug
Overproduction of the target enzyme

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism by which Enterococci develops resistance to vancomycin?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Modification of the target peptidoglycan precursor

 

Option A:

 

Vancomycin-resistant Enterococci (VRE) typically alter the D-Ala-D-Ala target site to D-Ala-D-Lac, preventing vancomycin binding.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Drug efflux pumps: While efflux pumps can confer resistance, it is not the primary mechanism for vancomycin resistance in Enterococci.

 

Option C. Enzymatic degradation of the drug: Enterococci do not generally enzymatically degrade vancomycin.

 

Option D. Overproduction of the target enzyme: Resistance is not due to overproduction of target enzymes but modification of the target site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterococci primarily develop vancomycin resistance through the modification of the target peptidoglycan precursor. 

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 67/4e

questions.text: New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase (NDM-1) confers resistance to which class of antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Carbapenems

 

Option D:

 

New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase (NDM-1) is an enzyme that confers resistance to carbapenems, a class of beta-lactam antibiotics. NDM-1 is a type of beta-lactamase enzyme that breaks down carbapenems, rendering them ineffective. Additionally, recognizing that NDM-1 does not confer resistance to other antibiotic classes such as tetracyclines, macrolides, and aminoglycosides is important for considering alternative treatment options. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tetracyclines: Incorrect. NDM-1 does not confer resistance to tetracyclines.

 

Option B. Macrolides: Incorrect. NDM-1 does not confer resistance to macrolides.

 

Option C. Aminoglycosides: Incorrect. NDM-1 is a type of beta-lactamase, not an aminoglycoside-modifying enzyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NDM-1 is a carbapenemase, conferring resistance to carbapenems.

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 67/4e

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with biofilm formation on indwelling medical devices?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Catheter-associated urinary tract infections

 

Option B:

 

Biofilm formation on urinary catheters is a common pathogenesis for catheter-associated UTIs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute otitis media: Typically caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae or Haemophilus influenzae and not associated with biofilms on devices.

 

Option C. Osteomyelitis: It can involve biofilms but is not commonly associated with indwelling devices.

 

Option D. Community-acquired pneumonia: Typically not associated with indwelling devices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biofilm formation on indwelling urinary catheters is a common cause of catheter-associated urinary tract infection.

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 69/4e

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis via ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor 2?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diphtheria toxin

 

Option C:

 

Toxin acts via ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor 2, inhibiting protein synthesis and leading to cell death.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cholera toxin: Incorrect. Cholera toxin ADP-ribosylation the Gs protein, leading to increased cAMP.

 

Option B. Shiga toxin: Incorrect. Shiga toxin inactivates the 60S ribosomal subunit, leading to inhibition of protein synthesis, but not through ADP-ribosylation of EF-2.

 

Option D. Pertussis toxin: Pertussis toxin ADP-ribosylation the Gi protein, leading to increased cAMP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mechanism of diphtheria toxin, which inhibits protein synthesis through ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor 2, leading to cell death. This contrasts with other toxins like cholera toxin and pertussis toxin, which act through ADP-ribosylation affecting cAMP levels, and Shiga toxin, which inhibits protein synthesis by targeting the 60S ribosomal subunit, but not via ADP-ribosylation of EF-2.

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 99,600/4e

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a sore throat, low-grade fever, and a barking cough. Physical examination reveals a thick, gray membrane covering his tonsils and pharynx. His vaccination history is incomplete. Laboratory tests are ordered to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following diseases, suspected in this boy, is associated with a bacteriophage-encoded toxin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diphtheria

 

Option B:

 

The bacterium Corynebacterium diphtheriae causes diphtheria, and the potent toxin it produces, which leads to the characteristic symptoms, is encoded by a lysogenic bacteriophage within the bacterium. This phage-mediated toxin production is a classic example of bacterial pathogenicity influenced by a virus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Botulism: Botulinum toxin is encoded by the bacterial genome of Clostridium botulinum, not by a bacteriophage.

 

Option C. Tetanus: Tetanus toxin is produced by Clostridium tetani and is not phage-coded.

 

Option D. Cholera: While cholera toxin is encoded by a bacteriophage, the question specifically asks for diseases associated with a bacteriophage-encoded toxin, and diphtheria is the classic example.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae, is uniquely associated with a toxin encoded by a lysogenic bacteriophage within the bacterium, distinguishing it from other diseases like botulism, tetanus, and cholera, where the toxins are not bacteriophage-encoded they are plasmid mediated.

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 99/4e

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with respiratory symptoms is admitted to the hospital. His chest X-ray reveals bilateral interstitial infiltrates, and a subsequent bronchoalveolar lavage is performed. Microscopic examination of the lavage fluid shows foamy, eosinophilic material. Based on these findings, which of the following organisms, known for being difficult or impossible to cultivate in artificial media, is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pneumocystis jirovecii

 

Option D:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii, an opportunistic fungal pathogen, cannot be cultured in routine laboratory media. It is commonly associated with pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS. The diagnosis is often made through direct visualization of the organism in respiratory samples, like bronchoalveolar lavage or induced sputum, using special stains like Diff-Quik, Grocott-Gomori methenamine silver (GMS), and Calcofluor white stains. or immunofluorescence. 

 

 

Picture showing Cysts of P. jirovecii in lung tissue, stained with methenamine silver and hematoxylin & eosin (H&E). The walls of the cysts are stained black; the intracystic bodies are not visible with this stain.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium leprae - Is also non-cultivable in artificial media. Diagnosis is typically established through clinical and histopathological findings.

 

Option B. Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis - This can be cultured. Diagnosis involves isolation of the organism and histopathological examination of affected tissues.

 

Option C. Rhinosporidium seeberi - This is cultivable. It forms distinctive sporangia, aiding in its identification through histopathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii, a common cause of pneumonia in immunocompromised patients, cannot be cultured and is diagnosed through visualization of the organism in respiratory samples using special stains like Diff-Quik, Grocott-Gomori methenamine silver (GMS), and Calcofluor white stains.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg116/4e

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a sore throat, fever, and the presence of a grayish-white membrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. A throat swab is collected, and the result of microscopic examination is shown in the image. Identify the organism and tell the other name of this organism.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kleb-Loeffler bacillus

 

Option B:

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae is also known as the Kleb-Loeffler bacillus. This name honors Friedrich Loeffler and Edwin Klebs, who were instrumental in isolating and identifying the bacterium. The characteristic Chinese-letter arrangement of the bacteria is a key microscopic finding that supports the diagnosis of diphtheria.

 

It is the causative organism of Diphtheria, a respiratory illness characterized by the formation of a pseudomembrane in the throat. 

 

The characteristic Chinese-letter arrangement of gram-positive rods can be observed in clinical samples.

 

 

 

Albert stain image of green bacilli with blue-green metachromatic granules arranged in chinese letter pattern- suggestive of C. diphtheriae

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Koch’s bacillus - Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative agent of Tuberculosis

 

Option C. Roux bacillus - “Roux bacillus" is not commonly used as an alternative name for Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Option D. Yersin bacillus - The causative agent of bubonic plague

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae (Kleb-Loeffler bacillus) - Is recognized by its characteristic Chinese-letter arrangement of gram-positive rods on microscopic examination. The knowledge of this organism's unique features, including its role in causing diphtheria characterized by the formation of a pseudomembrane in the throat, is crucial for medical practitioners. 

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 25,29/4e

choices.text: Direct inoculation of bacteria into the bloodstream during catheter insertion
Hematogenous spread from a distant infection site
Formation of biofilms on the catheter surface
Leakage of infusate along the outside of the catheter

questions.text: A patient in the intensive care unit develops a central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI). The medical team is discussing the pathophysiology of these infections in relation to central venous catheters. What is the primary mechanism by which central lines predispose patients to bloodstream infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Formation of biofilms on the catheter surface

 

Option C:

 

Central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs) are often attributed to the formation of biofilms on the surfaces of central venous catheters. 

 

Biofilms consist of microbial communities that adhere to the catheter surface and are embedded within a self-produced matrix of extracellular polymeric substances. This biofilm formation is significant because it not only provides a reservoir for pathogens but also confers increased resistance to antibiotics and host immune responses, leading to persistent and recurrent infections.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Direct inoculation of bacteria into the bloodstream during catheter insertion is a risk at the time of catheter placement but does not explain the ongoing risk of infection.

 

Option B. Hematogenous spread from a distant infection site can occur but is not the primary mechanism of CLABSI.

 

Option D. Leakage of infusate along the outside of the catheter may lead to local infection but is less likely to be a primary cause of bloodstream infections.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The primary mechanism contributing to central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs) is the formation of biofilms on the surfaces of central venous catheters. Biofilms, composed of microbial communities embedded in a self-produced extracellular matrix, provide a reservoir for pathogens and confer increased resistance to antibiotics and immune responses, leading to persistent or recurrent infections.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 69/4e

choices.text: Platelet-fibrin thrombi on the diseased valve
Atherosclerotic plaques within coronary arteries

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman with a known history of mitral valve prolapse presents to the clinic with fever and a mid-systolic click followed by a late-systolic murmur upon auscultation one week after a dental procedure. Gram-positive bacteria capable of synthesizing dextrans from sucrose are isolated from her blood cultures. Which structure is the most likely initial site of attachment for these bacteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Platelet-fibrin thrombi on the diseased valve

 

Option B:

 

 The bacteria described are likely to be Streptococcus viridans, which is known to bind to fibrin-platelet aggregates on damaged heart valves, leading to subacute bacterial endocarditis, especially after dental procedures where transient bacteremia can occur.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Prosthetic heart valve material: the patient does not have a history of valve replacement, and the question does not indicate the presence of a prosthetic valve.

 

Option C. Healthy endothelial tissue: S. viridans typically do not adhere to healthy endothelium.

 

Option D. Atherosclerotic plaques within coronary arteries: these structures are not typically the primary site of attachment for the bacteria responsible for endocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Platelet-fibrin thrombi on a diseased heart valve as the most likely site of bacterial adherence in endocarditis caused by Gram-positive bacteria that synthesize dextrans, such as Streptococcus viridans.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology, pg 4/4e

choices.text: Antigenic drift in HCV envelope proteins
Immune complex formation with HCV envelope proteins
Poor B-cell response to HCV envelope proteins
Non-neutralizing nature of the antibodies against HCV envelope proteins

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with abnormal liver enzyme tests but no significant symptoms. He tests positive for hepatitis C with no history of alcohol abuse or hepatotoxic medication use. Despite high titers of IgG antibodies against the hepatitis C virus (HCV) envelope protein, he remains viremic. What is the most plausible explanation for the lack of effective immunity conferred by these antibodies?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-neutralizing nature of the antibodies against HCV envelope proteins 

 

Option D:

 

The antibodies may be unable to neutralize the virus despite being present in high titers. This could be due to the inability of the antibodies to bind to crucial epitopes on the envelope protein that are necessary to prevent the virus from infecting cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Antigenic drift in HCV envelope proteins: While antigenic drift can occur in HCV, leading to immune evasion, it does not directly address the function of the antibodies.

 

Option B. Immune complex formation with HCV envelope proteins: The formation of immune complexes typically leads to the clearance of the virus, not persistent infection.

 

Option C. Poor B-cell response to HCV envelope proteins: A poor B-cell response would not result in high titers of antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of high titers of IgG antibodies against Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) envelope proteins does not guarantee effective immunity, especially if these antibodies lack neutralizing capabilities. 

 

Ref: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20357091/

choices.text: High cost of operation
Lack of colour in images

questions.text: What is the primary reason electron microscopy cannot be used to observe living organisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Requirement for a vacuum environment

 

Option B:

 

Living organisms cannot survive in the vacuum required for electron microscopy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. High cost of operation: While costly, this is not the primary reason.

 

Option C. Lack of color in images: The lack of color is not a factor in the inability to observe living organisms.

 

Option D. Size of the microscope: The size of the microscope has no bearing on its ability to observe living organisms.

 

Educational Objective:


The primary reason electron microscopy cannot be used to observe living organisms is the requirement for a vacuum environment. This environment is necessary for the operation of electron microscopes but is not conducive to sustaining life, as living organisms cannot survive in such conditions. 

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg10/4e

questions.text: In treating a Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection known to produce extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs), which antibiotic combination would be least effective?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Piperacillin and Tazobactam

 

Option D:

 

Piperacillin alone would not be effective against ESBL-producing Pseudomonas; however, in combination with tazobactam, a beta-lactamase inhibitor, it can regain its activity. This combination is typically effective, but given the options, it would be least effective if the ESBL produced by Pseudomonas can hydrolyze the piperacillin even in the presence of tazobactam.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. Ceftazidime and Amikacin: Ceftazidime is a cephalosporin with activity against Pseudomonas and when combined with amikacin, an aminoglycoside, can be effective against ESBL-producing strains.

 

Option B. Cefepime and Levofloxacin: Cefepime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin with anti-Pseudomonal activity, and levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone that can be effective in combination.

 

Option C. Meropenem and Tobramycin: Meropenem is a carbapenem that is generally effective against ESBL-producing bacteria, and tobramycin is an aminoglycoside that can cover Pseudomonas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ESBL-producing Pseudomonas aeruginosa - effective treatment options are Ceftazidime and Amikacin, Cefepime and Levofloxacin, and Meropenem and Tobramycin.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 65/4e

choices.text: Virulent Streptococcus pneumoniae with a smooth capsule
Non-virulent Streptococcus pneumoniae without a capsule

questions.text: Which bacterial strain was utilized in Griffith's transformation experiment to demonstrate the "transforming principle"?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Virulent Streptococcus pneumoniae with a smooth capsule

 

Option B:

 

Griffith's experiment used both non-pathogenic and virulent strains with a smooth capsule, which were able to transform the non-pathogenic strain into a pathogenic form.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Non-pathogenic Streptococcus pneumoniae:The non-pathogenic strain alone was not sufficient to demonstrate transformation.

 

Option C. Non-virulent Streptococcus pneumoniae without a capsule: While used in the experiment, the non-virulent, non-capsulated strain was not the transformative agent.

 

Option D. Virulent Streptococcus pyogenes: S. pyogenes was not part of Griffith's experiment; it was Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Smooth, encapsulated Streptococcus pneumoniae strain is used in demonstrating the principle of transformation in Griffith's experiment.

 

Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 55/4e

choices.text: To facilitate horizontal gene transfer between bacterial cells
To enable bacteria to resist viral infections through sequence-specific DNA cleavage
To allow the incorporation of viral DNA into the bacterial genome
To protect bacteria from the eukaryotic immune system

questions.text: What is the primary function of the CRISPR system in bacteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To enable bacteria to resist viral infections through sequence-specific DNA cleavage.

 

Option B:

 

CRISPR systems (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats) - The primary function of the CRISPR system in bacteria is to provide adaptive immunity against phage infections through the sequence-specific cleavage of foreign DNA.  CRISPR's role is specifically defensive, targeting and neutralizing invading phage DNA rather than assimilating or expressing it. This system is also distinct in its purpose from protecting bacteria against the eukaryotic immune system, as its primary focus is on phage defense.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. To facilitate horizontal gene transfer between bacterial cells: Incorrect. CRISPR is not directly involved in horizontal gene transfer.

 

Option C. To allow the incorporation of viral DNA into the bacterial genome: Incorrect. While CRISPR does involve the incorporation of spacer sequences, its function is defense, not integration for expression.

 

Option D. To protect bacteria from the eukaryotic immune system: Incorrect. CRISPR is a bacterial defense against viruses, not a protection mechanism against the eukaryotic immune system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR systems (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats)  provide bacteria with adaptive immunity against phages by targeting and cleaving foreign DNA sequences. 

 

Ref: https://www.genome.gov/genetics-glossary/CRISPR

questions.text: A researcher is studying a sample that requires visualization of intracellular organelles with high resolution. Which microscopy technique would offer the highest resolving power for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Electron Microscopy

 

Option D:

 

Electron microscopy provides the highest resolution and is capable of visualizing structures at the molecular level, making it ideal for studying intracellular organelles. This is because electron microscopes use a beam of electrons instead of light, allowing for a much higher resolving power than light-based microscopy techniques. Utilizes electron beams for imaging, allowing for much higher resolution than light-based methods.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Light Microscopy is versatile and widely used but has a limited resolving power due to the wavelength of visible light. Uses visible light; limited in resolution due to the wavelength of light.

 

Option B. Fluorescent Microscopy is excellent for specific tagging and visualization of certain cell components but does not inherently increase resolving power beyond that of standard light microscopy. Provides specific tagging of molecules with fluorescent markers; resolution similar to light microscopy.

 

Option C. Phase Contrast Microscopy enhances contrast in transparent samples without staining, but its resolving power is like that of conventional light microscopy. Improves contrast in unstained, transparent samples, resolving power comparable to light microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 9-10/4e

choices.text: It allows for the visualization of live cells in real time.
It offers the highest resolving power compared to other microscopy techniques.
It enables specific visualization of structures or molecules labeled with fluorescent markers.
It is the most cost-effective microscopy technique available.

questions.text: What is the primary advantage of using a fluorescent microscope in cellular and molecular biology studies?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It enables specific visualization of structures or molecules labeled with fluorescent markers.

 

Option C:

 

Fluorescent microscopy is particularly valuable in cellular and molecular biology for its ability to selectively illuminate specific components of a cell or tissue, tagged with fluorescent dyes or markers. This specificity allows for detailed study of cellular structures and functions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Is possible with fluorescent microscopy. Visualization of live cells in real time

 

Option B. Is not a characteristic of fluorescent microscopy; electron microscopy typically provides higher resolving power.

 

Option D. Is not a defining feature of fluorescent microscopy. In fact, it can be more expensive than some basic microscopy techniques due to the need for specialized dyes and equipment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluorescent microscopy as a technique primarily used for specific visualization of cellular and molecular structures labeled with fluorescent markers, aiding in detailed biological studies.

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 9-10/4e

choices.text: It enables the visualization of intracellular organelles with high resolution.
It allows for the observation of live cells without the need for staining.
It provides three-dimensional images of cell structures.
It enhances contrast in fixed and stained tissue sections.

questions.text: What is the primary advantage of using a phase contrast microscope in cell biology studies?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It allows for the observation of live cells without the need for staining.

 

Option B:

 

It allows for the observation of live cells without the need for staining. Phase contrast microscopy is particularly useful in cell biology for its ability to enhance the contrast in unstained, transparent biological samples, such as living cells. This technique converts phase shifts in light passing through a transparent specimen to brightness changes in the image, allowing details to be visible without staining.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Is more characteristic of electron microscopy. Visualization of intracellular organelles with high resolution: More relevant to electron microscopy.

 

Option C. Are typically provided by techniques like confocal microscopy, not phase contrast microscopy. Confocal microscopy provides three-dimensional images of cell structures

 

Option D. Is not the primary use of phase contrast microscopy, as it is specifically valuable for observing live, unstained cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary advantage of phase contrast microscopy is to allow the observation of live cells without the need for staining, enhancing the contrast of transparent cellular structures.

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 9-10/4e

choices.text: To inhibit the growth of unwanted microorganisms.
To enhance the growth of fastidious organisms.
To differentiate between organisms based on their biochemical characteristics.
To provide a sterile environment for uncontaminated microbial growth.

questions.text: What is the primary function of indicator or differential media in microbiological analysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To differentiate between organisms based on their biochemical characteristics.

 

Option C:

 

Indicator or differential media are designed to differentiate between organisms based on their biochemical characteristics. This is typically achieved through color changes in the media, which occur because of specific metabolic reactions by the bacteria.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. Inhibition of growth is characteristic of selective media, not differential media.

 

Option B. Enhancement of growth of fastidious organisms is more associated with enrichment media.

 

Option D. Providing a sterile environment is a basic requirement of all culture media, not specific to differential media.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary function of indicator or differential media in microbiology is to differentiate between organisms based on their biochemical characteristics, often through color changes in the media.

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 32/4e

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is known to reside within macrophages as a part of its pathogenesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium tuberculosis

 

Option B:

 

M. tuberculosis survives and replicates within macrophages.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. Streptococcus pneumoniae: It is typically extracellular.

 

Option C. Clostridium perfringens: It is an extracellular organism and a spore-former.

 

Option D. Vibrio cholerae: Incorrect. It is an extracellular organism causing disease in the intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis as an intracellular organism that survives within macrophages.

 

Ref:  Apurva Sastry Essentials of Microbiology pg 69/4e

questions.text:
A 68-year-old female with a history of multiple sclerosis has been using a urinary catheter for the past two months. Recently, she developed symptoms of a urinary tract infection (UTI), including dysuria and fever. Urine culture was performed to identify the causative organism.
 

What is the most common causative organism of catheter-induced urinary tract infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E. coli

 

Option A: 

 

E. coli is the most common cause of catheter-induced UTI. It is a part of the normal flora of the gut and can easily contaminate the periurethral area, especially in females. Its ability to adhere to the catheter surface facilitates its dominance in catheter-associated urinary tract infections.

 

Remember 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Klebsiella: Although Klebsiella is a known UTI pathogen, it is less common compared to E. coli in catheter-associated UTIs.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas: Pseudomonas is more commonly associated with hospital-acquired infections and in patients with compromised immune systems, but not the most common in catheter-induced UTI.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus: It is more commonly associated with skin and soft tissue infections rather than UTIs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microorganism causing urinary tract infections.

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p340, 2/e p642,353,354
